instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SDA: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SDA? SMBUS_CHGR_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SCL: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SCL? SMBUS_CHGR_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL is a clock line on the data line between the system management controller(SMC), temperature sensors, GPU, and ALS(ambient light sensor). If this line is pulled down the machine may run slow or have the fans run fast all the time because the SMC can’t tell what the temperature of parts of the machine like fin stack are. Usual problem is bad webcam, unplug webcam to see if it fixes problem. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA is a data line between the system management controller(SMC), temperature sensors, GPU, and ALS(ambient light sensor). If this line is pulled down the machine may run slow or have the fans run fast all the time because the SMC can’t tell what the temperature of parts of the machine like fin stack are. Usual problem is bad webcam, unplug webcam to see if it fixes problem. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Hey guys, I have here a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no power.

Green then Orange light, when pressing power CPU heats up, then trackpad is clickable for a few seconds.

then the trackpad is not clickable and CPU cools back down.

I have tried original 60w magsafe 2, I have tried multiple charged batteries, that are fully OEM, pulled from other machines, I have tried a working/tested trackpad, and trackpad cable.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.27V // 250 ohms
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4V // 10k ohms
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4V // 18k ohms
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5v // 18k ohms
[B]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 5V <--- WHEN POWERING ON, BUT THEN IT GOES DOWN TO .2V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5V // [/B]13k ohms [B]<--- WHEN POWERING ON, BUT THEN IT GOES DOWN TO .2V [/B]
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> - 3.4V // 87k ohms
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.4V 

Board is completely clean, never been messed with, all screws were untouched.

Any other voltages I can test?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Try if board stays on starting in SMC bypass mode.
Test the board disconnecting anything.
Just keep DCIN board and use USB mouse for test.

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.27V"
Incorrect voltage"
Post exact resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Also post voltage and diode mode on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage

[/QUOTE]

Hi and thank you for responding, I have tried SMC bypass mode and that does not work, is the correct way of doing SMC bypass by unplugging the laptop, holding the power button for 10 secs, plugging the computer back in while holding the power button for an additional 10 secs and then releasing and pressing it again to get it to boot.

Also, doesnt the 2015 macbook pro need a good battery, trackpad, and keyboard attached to start up, I heard they act kind of funny.

[QUOTE]
Also post voltage and diode mode on SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.[/QUOTE] 
I am not 100% sure what those mean, are you talking about the [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_1_S0_SDA</SIGNAL> [/B]and the [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_1_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> [/B]line?

Will report back with resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Do NOT quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Maintain forum aesthetic, please.

This board should start by itself when charger is connected.
You can trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal for test to check other reactions on the board.

I was reffering to SCL/SDA lines common to battery, <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Sorry about quoting,

I will Use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads for that.
Solder a tiny wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and simulate power button touching some metal plate from chassis, is that correct?

When it comes to SCL/SDA Lines do you mean

ISL(<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>)
PIN 10 which is [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SCL</SIGNAL>[/B]
PIN 11 which is [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL>[/B]

SMC(<CHIP>U5000</CHIP>)
<RESISTOR>R5351</RESISTOR> which is [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL>[/B]
<RESISTOR>R5350</RESISTOR> which is <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA</SIGNAL>

Battery
Not sure about the scl/sda lines, if you can let me know.

Please let me know if I am heading in the right direction.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
ISL(<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>)
PIN 10 which is [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SCL</SIGNAL> = [/B]3.4V // 12.5k OHMS
PIN 11 which is [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL> = [/B]3.4V // 12.5k OHMS

SMC(<CHIP>U5000</CHIP>)
<RESISTOR>R5351</RESISTOR> which is [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SCL</SIGNAL> [/B]= 0.08v // 33.5K OHMS
<RESISTOR>R5350</RESISTOR> which is [B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_0_S0_SDA</SIGNAL> [/B] = 0.08v // 33.5K OHMS

Shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground does nothing at all.

threads.message:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
"Will report back with resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>"

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
pin 17 = 70k ohms
pin 18 = 7.2k ohms
pin 27 = (OL) Open Line
pin 28 = (OL) Open Line

"Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?"
yes I do <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.42V

thank you for your support.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
Resistance between pin 17 & 18 = 4.0 Ohms
Resistance between pins 27 & 28 = 20.7 Ohms

You do not think it is problem with SMC? As it might be dead?

Something wrong with SMC-<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> communication.
Please podt diode mode readings (red probe at ground) on SCL/SDA lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
You still mix the things here.
If we talk about the SAME (common) bus between different chips, why do you check <RESISTOR>R5350</RESISTOR>/51???
Battery bus is SMBus 5.
And which is the reason to try measuring the same line in different points?

The readings look good.
In this case I recommend to change first <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
If no result, reball/change SMC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction (drop pulse) at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>; use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
Thank you so much for the continuous support you are giving me! I very much appreciate it.

[B]VOLTAGE // OHMS MODE // DIODE MODE[/B]

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.34v // 300Ohms and climbing // 0.1V (diode mode)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.34v // 10K Ohms and climbing // 0.425V (diode mode)

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.34v // 130k Ohms and climbing // 0.625V (diode mode)

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4v // 2k Ohms climbing slow // 0.5V (diode mode)

when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> the <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> = drops from 3.4 to .35V

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0.1V // 10k Ohms and climbing // 0.5V (diode mode) (NO BATTERY CONNECTED???)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - No Power, No Liquid Damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> must be high if proper charger connected.
If not, PCH doesn't start power on sequence.
Be sure to use original Magsafe 2 60/85W charger.

Will test with a brand new charger from apple store, will go out and buy one today.
